channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Do some good in the world â€“ Perl developers required for a charity team in Kent, UK.
item.description: Want to do something good for once? Join the Kickstarter of the charity world, supporting activists and causes around the world. Youâ€™ll be working in Perl to support a range of their highly successful charity and giving-focused projects.

item.title: Put your Perl skills into action in a young, green city that leaves more greenbacks in your pocket.
item.description: Youâ€™ll be working for a Pittsburgh-based hosting company, well-known and well-respected within Perl circles. Serving over 120 countries worldwide and with their skin in the game for a quarter century.

item.title: Could you service an audience of 10 Million+?
item.description: Sometimes when young companies reach a certain level of success, complacency sets in. The culture (subtly) shifts from entrepreneurial to bureaucratic. Thatâ€™s not this client. Instead of toasting themselves, they keep rolling.

item.title: All in the Family - Perl developer in Central Manchester
item.description: Family is great, but working with them can be a nightmare, am I right? Cousin Edward nipping out early, Aunt Phyllis getting into the sherry before closing time . . . But what if you could get close-knit clan vibes working with a large company that started out as a family business?

item.title: Superheroes Spotted in Canary Wharf!
item.description: Look there, up in the sky: Itâ€™s a birdâ€”itâ€™s a planeâ€”itâ€™s you, saving UK job hunters from disaster one click at a time! This company has a dynamic, upbeat corporate culture that embraces positivity, enthusiasm, and new ideas. Theyâ€™ve got all the energy of a start-up with none of the drawbacks!

item.title: Barcelona Perl and Friends 2019
item.description: November 9, 2019 in Barcelona, Spain. A free one-day conference for Geeks and Friends

item.title: London Perl Workshop 2019
item.description: October 19, 2019. David Game College, 31 Jewry St, London EC3N 2ET

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Path to Raku
item.description: The opinion of Jonathan regarding the Perl 6 name change.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 27: Intersection Point and Historical Values
item.description: Laurent's blog is like reading a book, comprehensive analysis of each tasks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 027: Intersection of Straight Lines and Historical Data
item.description: Choroba took us back to school with a refresher for finding the intersection of two lines.

item.title: Historical Intersection with Perl 6
item.description: One thing special about Arne's blog other than his writing skill, is the catchy title.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 027
item.description: Adam shares how he used standard formula to figure out intersection of two lines.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Roger Bell_West
item.description: Please check out the short interview with the "Perl Weekly Challenge - 026" winner Roger Bell_West.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 027
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 028
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: perlres - List of resources about Perl
item.description: A huge list of Perl-related resource. Hosted in a GitHub repository so you can easily send suggestions in the form of a Pull-Request. If you do it in October, you might even earn a T-shirt.

item.title: Hacktoberfest 2019 and Perl
item.description: Some low-hanging fruits of PRs that can help improve the overall health of the CPAN ecosystem.

item.title: Hacktoberfest with Perl Weekly Challenge
item.description: If you do the Perl Weekly Challenges every week then you'll have more than enough PRs to meet the requirements. However Mohammad wants more. With enough people doing the Perl Weekly Challenge he wants it to be a star in the overall competition of projects that got the most Pull-requests in October.

item.title: Hacktoberfest 2019
item.description: Hacktoberfest starts tomorrow. brian d foy gives you some directions what to hack on if you'd like to participate. It is fun even if you don't want the T-shirt.

item.title: #427 - Hacktoberfest starts tomorrow
item.description:
Hi there!

Hacktoberfest is the annual excuse created by Digital Ocean to contribute to an Open Source project.

According to the most recent survey of Stack Overflow 36% of their respondents have never contributed to Open Source and 28% did that less than once a year.

If you are among these 54% it is a very good opportunity to participate in the Hacktoberfest and use that as an excuse to learn how to make a change or to have at least 4 contributions this year.

If you are an experienced contributor, then just keep doing your thing. On the long run it pays off.

There are 3 posts dealing with Perl and the Hacktoberfest. Find the one that fits you and let us know about your progress!

Enjoy your week!
